questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
While actin belongs to a separate class of cytoskeletal proteins called microfilaments, the other three (lamin, vimentin, and desmin) belong to the group of intermediate filaments.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins, namely, microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

Cytoskeletal proteins:

1. Actin microfilaments:

  • These are 5- to 9-nm diameter fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin). The G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments

  • These are 10-nm diameter fibrils that include family of related proteins sharing common structural and sequence features. Individual types have characteristic tissue-specific patterns of expression that can be useful for assigning a cell of origin for poorly differentiated tumors.
  • These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not usually actively reorganize like actin and microtubules. They impart tensile strength and allow cells to bear mechanical stress.
Type of intermediate filament (IF) protein Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. The nuclear membrane lamins are responsible for maintaining nuclear morphology and nuclear transcription. Mutations In lamin proteins is associated with certain disorders such as muscular dystrophy and progeria.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts and endothelial cells)
Desmin These proteins are mainly present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are present in the axons of neurons and impart strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein These are present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins. There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair keratin).

 

3. Microtubules: These are 25-nm-thick fibrils formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin and beta-tubulin.  These dimers polymerize such that the beta-subunit of one dimer combines with the alpha-subunit of another dimer. The polymerization of these dimers leads to the formation of protofilament, where one end of it has a beta-subunit exposed (designated as + end), while the other end has an alpha-subunit exposed (designated as – end). The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of physiological atrophy?

choices.text: Atrophy of the legs of a bedridden patient
Atrophy of the arm muscles following a nerve injury
Muscle wasting in a child suffering from marasmus
Uterine atrophy after delivery by Cesarean-section

questions.solution:
Uterine atrophy following delivery is an example of physiological atrophy.

Atrophy is defined as a reduction in the size of an organ or tissue due to a decrease in cell size and number.

The following mechanisms are involved in atrophy:

  • Decreased protein synthesis due to decreased metabolic activity
  • Increased destruction of proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

The various types of atrophy are:

Stimulus/type of atrophy Example
Physiologic atrophy
Loss of hormonal stimulation

Atrophy of the uterus after parturition

Atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause
During embryonic development Certain structures, like notochord and thyroglossal duct
Pathologic atrophy
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: Who discovered the process of phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov discovered the process of phagocytosis. He is known as the father of natural immunity and established the concept of cell-mediated immunity.

He was jointly awarded the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology along with Paul Ehrlich, who established the concept of humoral immunity.

questions.text: The following finding was noted on the cardiac tissue specimen of an 82-year-old man. Which of the following is false about the given finding?

choices.text: It is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury
It is injurious to the cell and its function
It is derived through lipid peroxidation
It can also be seen in liver of aging patients

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows yellow-brown lipochrome or lipofuscin pigment. It is not injurious to the cell or its functions.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment derived from the peroxidation of lipids of subcellular membranes. It is an indicator of free radical injury to the cells.

It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material that is seen in the liver, brain, and heart due to normal aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

It can also be seen in patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.text: The prothrombin time of a patient with menorrhagia is being estimated. Which factor initiates the clotting pathway being tested here?
questions.solution:
The prothrombin time tests the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. This is initiated by the tissue factor.

To test the extrinsic pathway, clotting is initiated in the laboratory by adding a source of tissue factor which combines with factor VIIa. It is the major initiator of coagulation in vivo and is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

To test the intrinsic pathway, clotting is initiated in the laboratory by adding phospholipids, calcium, or a negatively charged substance such as glass beads. The intrinsic pathway is kicked off in the body by thrombin.

The coagulation cascade is depicted in the image below.

questions.text: After evaluation, a patient with the given finding is diagnosed with Bourneville disease. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)/ Bourneville disease is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder.

TSC affects the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development. This results in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the body. Two distinct genetic loci have been identified which are on chromosome  9 (TSC1) and on chromosome 16 (TSC2).

The most common cutaneous manifestation of TSC is hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf macules) and is observed in most children with tuberous sclerosis. It presents at birth or appears within the first few years of life and may fade or disappear in adulthood.

The following image shows an ash-leaf macule.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Tay–Sachs Disease?

choices.text: Affected infants are normal at birth
Neurons in the CNS, ANS, and retina are affected
Accumulations stain positive for oil red O and Sudan black B
Whorled configurations within mitochondria are seen

questions.solution:
In Tay–Sachs disease, an electron microscope shows whorled configurations within lysosomes composed of onion-skin layers of membranes.

Affected infants appear normal at birth but begin to manifest signs and symptoms at about 6 months of age. The involvement of neurons in the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina dominates the clinical picture.

There is a severe motor and mental deterioration, beginning with motor incoordination and mental obtundation. This leads to muscular flaccidity, blindness, and increasing dementia. Over the span of 1 or 2 years, a completely vegetative state is reached, followed by death at age 2 to 3 years

On histologic examination, the neurons are ballooned with cytoplasmic vacuoles, each representing a markedly distended lysosome filled with gangliosides.

A cherry-red spot appears in the macula, representing the accentuation of the normal color of the macular choroid. This is in contrast with the pallor produced by the swollen ganglion cells in the remainder of the retina. This finding is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease and other storage disorders affecting the neurons.

The image given below shows a cherry-red spot on retina.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of cholangiocarcinoma presents with intermittent fever and jaundice. Which of the following organisms is commonly implicated in the pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Opisthorchis viverrini (liver fluke) is implicated in the pathogenesis of cholangiocarcinoma.

Apart from Opisthorchis viverrini, Clonorchis sinensis is also known to cause cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following procarcinogens does not require metabolic activation?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide is a directly-acting carcinogen that does not require metabolic activation.

Carcinogens can be direct-acting or indirect-acting based on their activation.

Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weak carcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs (e.g., alkylating agents). The direct-acting carcinogens include:

  • Alkylating Agents:
    • β-Propiolactone
    • Dimethyl sulfate
    • Diepoxybutane
    • Anticancer drugs (cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, nitrosoureas, and others)
  • Acylating Agents:
    • 1-Acetyl-imidazole
    • Dimethylcarbamyl chloride

Indirect-acting carcinogens (procarcinogens) are chemicals that require metabolic conversion to become active carcinogens. The carcinogenic product of metabolism is called an ultimate carcinogen. The indirect-acting carcinogens include:

  • Polycyclic and heterocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons:
    • Benz[a]anthracene
    • Benzo[a]pyrene
    • Dibenz[a,h]anthracene
    • 3-Methylcholanthrene
    • 7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene
  • Aromatic amines, amides, azo dyes:
    • 2-Naphthylamine (β-naphthylamine)
    • Benzidine
    • 2-Acetylaminofluorene
    • Dimethylaminoazobenzene (butter yellow)
  • Natural plant and microbial products:
    • Aflatoxin B1
    • Griseofulvin
    • Cycasin
    • Safrole
    • Betel nuts
    • Others
    • Nitrosamine and amides
    • Vinyl chloride, nickel, chromium
    • Insecticides, fungicides
    • Polychlorinated biphenyls

questions.text: What is the thickness of the normal left ventricular wall?
questions.solution:
Normal left ventricular wall thickness is 1.3 to 1.5 cm.

Normal right ventricular wall thickness is 0.3 to 0.5 cm.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea for the past 2 months. He has no history of cardiac disease. Examination revealed an ejection systolic murmur. Transesophageal echocardiography was done, which revealed an aortic valve with 2 functional cusps and a valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to abnormal fusion of valve commissures
Midline of larger cusp is major site of calcification

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and echo findings are suggestive of calcific aortic stenosis secondary to bicuspid aortic valve (2 functional cusps). It is due to incomplete separation of valve commissures during development, not abnormal fusion.

In a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve, the 2 functional cusps are usually of unequal size. The larger cusp has a midline raphe that results from incomplete commissural separation during development. The raphe is frequently a major site of calcific deposits.

This condition is associated with mutations in the following areas:

  • Chromosomes 18q, 5q, and 13q 
  • Chromosome 9q - loss-of-function mutations in NOTCH1 gene

Late complications include:

  • Aortic stenosis or regurgitation
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Aortic dilation and/or dissection.
  • Predisposed to progressive calcification - Approximately 50% of cases of aortic stenosis in adults.

Note: Acquired bicuspid valves result from abnormal fusion of valve commissures because of an acquired deformity (rheumatic valve disease). It produces a conjoined cusp that is generally twice the size of the nonconjoined cusp.

questions.text: A 43 year-old-male patient came to the clinic with complaints of occasional hematuria and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Examination revealed tiny petechial hemorrhages over his lower limbs. The patient tests positive for the anti-proteinase-3 antibody. Which of the following is true about this major antibody?

choices.text: It is also known as p-ANCA
It shows perinuclear staining on immunofluorescence

questions.solution:
Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA is triggered by certain infections as proteinase 3 shares similarities with many microbial peptides. This is the major antibody responsible for Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA). 

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against the constituents of neutrophils or monocytes. Many patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.

The two most important ANCAs related to vasculitis are: 

  • Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA - Directed against PR3 which is a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent.
  • Anti-myeloperoxidase/MPO-ANCA/p-ANCA - Directed against MPO which is a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by several therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil. 

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

questions.text: The best investigation for diagnosing temporal arteritis is_____
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Temporal arteriitis depends on biopsy and histologic confirmation. However, because giant cell arteritis can be extremely focal within an artery, adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment; even then, a negative biopsy result does not exclude the diagnosis.

Findings

  • Intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • Medial granulomatous inflammation centered on the internal elastic lamina that produces elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • Infiltrate of T cells (CD4+ >CD8+) and macrophages,multinucleated giant cells.

Image - Giant cell arteritis intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a testicular mass. Microscopic examination of the orchidectomy specimen was done. It showed highly anaplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli growing in alveolar and tubular patterns. They stained positive for  PLAP, cytokeratin, and CD30 and negative for KIT.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of the germ-cell tumor is suggestive of embryonal carcinoma. 

It is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCTs) that occurs mostly in the 20 to 30 year age group. These tumors are more aggressive than seminomas. Embryonal carcinomas share some markers with seminomas such as OCT 3/4 and PLAP but differ by being positive for cytokeratin and CD30 and negative for KIT.

Most patients present with a testicular mass, which can be painful due to rapid growth and may be mistaken for torsion.

Grossly, the tumor is often variegated, poorly demarcated at the margins, and punctuated by foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.

Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary convolutions; the neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli.

The below image is the histology of embryonal carcinoma showing anaplastic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei.

Option A: Seminoma will have sheets of uniform cells with poor, demarcated lobules divided by delicate fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes. Seminomas are positive PLAP and KIT, but negative for cytokeratin and CD30.

Option C: Teratoma will show derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hairs, sebaceous glands in the histology.

Option D: Yolk sac tumor affects children up to 3 yrs of age, will have elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), and exhibit Schiller–Duval bodies on histology.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body and frothy urine. Urinary examination revealed grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. There were no red blood cells in the urine. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?

choices.text: IgA nephropathy is the likely diagnosis.
It is associated with low C3 levels.
No IgG  or C3 deposition is seen on renal biopsy.
Alport syndrome is the likely diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in this child is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). It is characterized by the absence of immune deposits on biopsy and histopathological examination. 

It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years).

Biopsy findings of MCD are as follows:

  • Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change')
  • Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Caspase cleaves proteins at:
questions.solution:
Caspases are cysteine proteases that cleave proteins at the aspartic acid residue. Hence, the activation of caspases plays a key role in the process of apoptosis.

The activation of caspases depends on a finely tuned balance between production of pro- and anti-apoptotic proteins.

Two distinct pathways converge on caspase activation:

  • The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway
  • The death receptor (extrinsic) pathway

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make you suspect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate.  It is found in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific finding.

Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth. It is seen in renal TB.

questions.text: The accumulation of aggregates of the protein ______ is associated with Parkinson disease and multiple system atrophy.
questions.solution:
The pathologic process that is common across most of the neurodegenerative diseases is the accumulation of protein aggregates, which is a morphologic hallmark of the disease.

The protein aggregates are recognized histologically as inclusions, which often are the diagnostic hallmark of the disease.

The basis for aggregation varies from one disease to another.

It may be directly related to an intrinsic feature of a mutated protein (e.g., expanded polyglutamine repeats in Huntington disease), an intrinsic feature of a peptide derived from a larger precursor protein (e.g., Aβ in Alzheimer disease), or an unexplained alteration of a normal cellular protein (e.g., α-synuclein in sporadic Parkinson disease).

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman complains about throbbing pain over both palms. Her examination findings and lab reports are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 11 g/dL

WBC - 9,000 /mm3

Platelet count - 7,00,000 /μL

Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellular with megakaryocytes and reticulin fibrils

Philadelphia chromosome - absent

MPL mutation - positive
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia.

Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling.

WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia:

  • Major criteria -
    • Platelet count ≥450 × 109/L
    • Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei
    • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms
    • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation
  • Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis

Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion

Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with increased Hb levels. 

Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. 

Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple, small, pink nodular growths on the temples. A biopsy from the lesion showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor). 

Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy epilation of the scalp. 

The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic‐like masses - a jigsaw appearance. Malignant transformation is very rare.

Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors:

  • Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma
  • Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma
  • Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenomas
  • Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmomas

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. Histopathological examination of the bone marrow aspirate showed the findings as given below. The findings seen on histopathology are due to the accumulation of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing Russell bodies are suggestive of multiple myeloma. These are globular, eosinophilic intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: An obese 35-year-old man with renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain in the right knee. It is associated with localized hyperemia. Joint aspiration is done which shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and the following finding under polarised light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals that are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent. 

Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate (MSU) within and around joints. This results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes. Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines.

The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are acute arthritis, chronic tophaceous arthritis, tophi in various sites, and gouty nephropathy. Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout. These are large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys.

Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior. The patient subsequently died and on autopsy, the following findings are seen in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these called?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum. These are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies. This patient's clinical features of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior are suggestive of rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

September 28 this year will mark the 17th World Rabies Day. This year’s theme, ‘All for 1, One Health for All’ highlights that One Health is not for a selected few but for everyone. The Central Government has launched the National Rabies Control Programme (NRCP) for the prevention and control of rabies.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?

choices.text: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11

questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome.

It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11.

It is characterized by:

  • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps 
  • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine cancer)

Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common monoclonal immunoglobulin seen in patients with myeloma?
questions.solution:
The most common monoclonal Ig (M protein) in myeloma is IgG (approximately 55% of patients), followed by IgA (approximately 25% of cases).

The immunosecretory disorders are a diverse group of diseases associated with the proliferation of an abnormal clone of immunoglobulin-synthesizing, terminally differentiated B cells. These disorders include:

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) and its variants
  • Plasmacytoma
  • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
  • Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance
  • Monoclonal Ig deposition diseases - Includes primary amyloidosis and nonamyloidotic types.

The immunoglobulin can be complete or can be composed of either heavy or light chains and is termed M-(monoclonal) protein. Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 gm/dL of serum immunoglobulin. Myelomas expressing IgM, IgD, or IgE occur, but they are rare.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with colicky abdominal pain and purpuric skin lesions on the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs. Urine analysis reveals hematuria and mild proteinuria. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder, commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. The patient may present with the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks
  • Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding.
  • Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in the adults

It is strongly associated with atopy in a few patients, and the onset often follows an upper respiratory infection. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium for 6 months. His hemogram and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 10 gm/dL

TLC - 5.5 lakhs/mm3

Platelet count - 4 lakhs/mm3
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%) 

Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. The following finding was noted on examination. Genetic testing revealed a dystrophin gene mutation. On which chromosome is the affected gene located?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition. 

Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.

Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern.

In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the antibodies of pernicious anaemia?

choices.text: Type I antibodies are found in both plasma and gastric juice
Type I antibody blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor
Type II antibodies prevent the binding of the IF-B12 complex to ileal receptors
Type III antibodies are against haptocorrin

questions.solution:
Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pumps.

Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. 

Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are:

  • Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both plasma and gastric juice
  • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its ileal receptor
  • Type III antibodies - recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a sample from a patient with amyloidosis. Which of the following is false about the specimen's appearance?

choices.text: Rose pink appearance under crystal violet stain
Mahogany brown color on iodine staining

questions.solution:
Amyloid shows apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy, after staining with Congo red.

The appearance of amyloid: 

  • Light microscopy - amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance
  • Congo red stain - the characteristic appearance using this stain is due to the cross-β-pleated sheet conformation
    • Under ordinary light, it appears pink or red color (as shown below) 

- Under the polarizing microscope - imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits (as shown in the image below)

  • Electron microscopy - continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm
  • X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy - Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation.

It appears mahogany brown on iodine staining and rose-pink on staining with crystal violet.

Related Pearl: Appearance of Amyloid

Methods Appearance
On light microscopy and standard tissue stains (H&E)  Amorphous eosinophilic extracellular substance 
Congo red stain on ordinary light    Pink or red colour to tissue deposits 
Congo red stain on polarizing microscopy   Apple-green birefringence 
Fluorescent stains (thioflavin T and S)    Yellow colour under UV light 
Electron microscopy  Nonbranching fibrils of indefinite length and a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm. 
X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy  Characteristic cross β pleated sheet conformation 

H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding precursor squamous epithelial lesions of the cervix?

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

choices.text: LSIL progress directly to invasive carcinoma
LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs
HPV-16 is the most common HPV type in both LSIL and HSIL
They progress to invasive carcinoma over many years

questions.solution:
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasive carcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), then invasive carcinoma.

The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low and high-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV type associated with both LSIL and HSIL

LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs.  Most of these lesions regress spontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL

80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia presents with a one-day history of bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleed, and purpuric rash. Investigations done are given below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?

Hb: 6.4 gm/dL

TLC: 26,500 cells/mm3

Platelet: 35,000 mm3

Prothrombin time: 20 sec with a control of 13 sec

Partial thromboplastin time: 50 sec

Fibrinogen: 10 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient shows features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It is most likely to be associated with acute myeloid leukemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia. The pathogenesis behind this is t(15,17) or PML-RARA fusion gene.

Option A: Inversion 16 is seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia or AML - M4. 

Option B: t(8;21) is seen in AML with differentiation or AML - M2.

Option C: Inversion 3 is seen in AML - M7 (megakaryoblastic) which shows normal or increased platelet count. It has a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. She returned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smear is given below. This condition is protective against which of the following malarial parasites?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bite cells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD deficiency. This condition is protective against Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

Malarial parasites preferentially invade RBCs which are rich in G6PD. G6PD deficiency causes oxidative stress and hemolysis, preferably in the older RBCs. Reticulocytes and young erythrocytes have much higher G6PD activities and are less susceptible to oxidant damage. 

P. falciparum can invade erythrocytes of all ages. P. vivax, and P. ovale invade reticulocytes (immature erythrocytes) preferentially. Hence, a low G6PD level in older RBC is protective against P. falciparum malaria.

Episodic hemolysis in this condition can be triggered by fava beans which is a staple in Egyptian cuisine.

The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: This photomicrograph from a liver biopsy seen below is most likely to have been obtained from a patient with________.
questions.solution:
The photomicrograph shows foci of enlarged hepatocytes with eosinophilic dull/hazy, somewhat irregular cytoplasm called ground-glass hepatocytes (Arrow).

Ground-glass hepatocyte (GGH) represents a histological hallmark of chronic hepatitis B virus infection and contains surface antigens in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes mellitus is on dialysis for chronic renal failure. Which of the following forms of gastritis is the patient at risk of development?
questions.solution:
Patients with renal failure develop acute gastritis as a consequence of uremia.

In uremia, gastric injury is due to inhibition of gastric bicarbonate transporters by ammonium ions.

Causes of acute gastritis:

  • Alcohol
  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Smoking
  • Ischemia/shock
  • Steroid use
  • Uremia
  • Chemical ingestion
  • Stress

Histologically, the presence of neutrophils above the basement membrane in direct contact with epithelial cells signifies acute gastritis.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is most common in India.

The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and young adults. It has an excellent prognosis.

Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a male predominance.

The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cells

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic developed cirrhosis of the liver. Which is the principal cell type involved in scar deposition in this condition?
questions.solution:
The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver is the hepatic stellate cell or Ito cell.

Hepatic stellate cells deposit primarily type I and type III collagen in the lobule and cause fibrosis. In their quiescent form, these cells store lipids and vitamin A.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is diagnosed to have idiopathic ITP. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are uncommon in idiopathic (primary) ITP. They are seen in secondary ITP.

Chronic ITP occurs most commonly in adult women younger than 40 years of age. The female-to-male ratio is 3: 1. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. It is of 2 types:

  • Primary or idiopathic - without any risk factors
  • Secondary - presence of predisposing conditions like SLE, HIV, CLL

Signs of accelerated thrombopoiesis that are seen in this condition are:

  • Megakaryocytes in bone marrow
  • Megathrombocytes (abnormally large platelets) in peripheral blood

The image given below shows 2 megakaryocytes seen in bone marrow aspirate (Wrights stain).

Acute ITP is mainly a disease of childhood. It occurs with equal frequency in both sexes, mostly after a viral illness. It is self-limited condition, resolves within 6 months.

questions.text: Translocations of which of the following proto-oncogenes is most likely present in patients with Burkitt lymphoma?
questions.solution:
All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels.

In addition to the MYC translocations in Burkitt lymphoma and a subset of other B and T cell tumours, MYC is amplified in some breast, colon, lung, and many other carcinomas.

The functionally identical NMYC and LMYC genes are also amplified in neuroblastomas and small-cell cancers of the lung, respectively.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy picture of lysosomes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Electron microscopy showing zebra bodies is suggestive of Niemann–Pick disease.

Zebra bodies are engorged secondary lysosomes that contain membranous cytoplasmic bodies resembling concentric lamellated myelin figures. Similar zebra bodies can also be seen in mucopolysaccharidoses.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Glial hamartia is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Glial hamartia are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2). These are microscopic nodular collections of glial cells at abnormal locations, often in the superficial and deep layers of the cerebral cortex. 

NF2 is associated with the following: 

  • Bilateral eighth-nerve schwannomas
  • Multiple meningiomas
  • Gliomas - typically ependymomas of the spinal cord
  • Nonneoplastic lesions - schwannosis, meningioangiomatosis, and glial hamartia

Option A: NF 1 is associated with neurofibromas of all types, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and pheochromocytomas.

Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with hamartomas within the CNS in the form of cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. Other lesions include subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma, renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, cardiac rhab­domyomas, and cysts in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas.

Option D: Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts involving the pancreas, liver, and kidneys, and have a propensity to develop renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

NOTE: A hamartia is not considered to be a tumor and is distinct from a hamartoma. A hamartoma is a benign neoplasm characterized by tissue misarrangement similar to a hamartia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a painless testicular mass. Inguinal orchidectomy was done and the gross and histological image is given below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen showing a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma is characteristic of a seminomatous germ-cell tumor or seminoma.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Seminoma is the most common type of GCT. The peak incidence is the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Option B: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years.

Option C: Teratoma shows derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hair, sebaceous glands.

Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. Fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: What is the most common type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)?
questions.solution:
The most common type of VSD is the membranous type.

Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) are classified according to their size and location. 

90% occur in the region of the membranous interventricular septum membranous VSD. Others occur below the pulmonary valve (infundibular VSD) or within the muscular septum. Although most VSDs are single, those in the muscular septum may be multiple.

 Image: Ventricular septal defect (schematic).

questions.text: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition.

Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice
  • Splenomegaly

Causes of extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia

Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Glanzmann thrombasthenia except______

choices.text: Platelets fail to aggregate in response to adenosine diphosphate (ADP)
Dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb IIIa, an integrin

questions.solution:
Glanzmann thrombasthenia is bleeding due to defective platelet aggregation, which is transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait.

The associated bleeding tendency is often severe.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in megaloblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anaemia has hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophil.

The basic pathophysiology of megaloblastic anaemia is impairment of DNA synthesis. This leads to ineffective and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Peripheral smear findings are:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Marked variation in the size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis) of red cells
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • Nucleated RBC progenitors, occasionally appearing in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe

Bone marrow findings are:

  • Markedly hypercellular, as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors
  • Granulocytic precursors, which exhibit dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, which may be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • Apoptosis of most precursors in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis), leading to pancytopenia; caused by a derangement in DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common trigger for hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is infection. Viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis.

Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include:

  • Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes
  • Drugs
    • Antimalarials - primaquine and chloroquine 
    • Sulfonamides
    • Nitrofurantoin
  • Diet - fava bean
